conversation.content: What if Gendry had the ability to stop time? How would key events play out? In detail, if you can.

If Gendry had the ability to stop time, it would significantly change the course of key events in the Game of Thrones storyline. Here is how some of the events would play out:

1. The Battle of the Blackwater: Gendry would be able to stop time as soon as Tywin Lannister's army arrived to prevent them from joining the battle. This would give Stannis Baratheon and his loyalists much-needed breathing room to successfully defeat Joffrey Baratheon’s army and take King’s Landing.

2. The Red Wedding: Gendry could have saved many of Robb Stark's loyalists if he had stopped time during the massacre. He could have fought off the assassins and rescued key characters like Catelyn, Robb, and Talisa.

3. The Battle of the Bastards: Gendry could have changed the entire course of this battle if he had been able to stop time. He could have intervened directly, taking out key figures like Ramsay Bolton, saving the lives of many Stark loyalists.

4. Daenerys' Dragons: Gendry could have potentially prevented the capture and death of Viserion by the Night King. By stopping time, he could have intervened in the battle and taken out the Night King or prevented him from getting close to the dragons.

5. The Death of Ned Stark: Gendry could have stopped time during the execution by King Joffrey and saved his life. However, this would have drastically changed the plot and direction of the story.

In conclusion, if Gendry had the ability to stop time, he could have changed the outcome of many key events in Game of Thrones. His actions would have disrupted the plot and changed the course of the entire story, but it is interesting to imagine how things could have been different.

conversation.content: Write a character who has extraordinary powers. But wants to be normal. Write why.

His name was Adam and since he was young, he always knew he was different. He possessed extraordinary powers that made him stand out from every other person. As a child, he used his powers to help his family and friends, but as he grew older, he realized that his powers came with a great responsibility.

Adam's powers were not just a gift but also a curse. His ability to manipulate matter, move faster than sound, and read people's minds made him feel isolated and alone. He could never connect with anyone on a deeper level, and it made him feel like an outcast.

As he entered his teenage years, Adam's desire to be normal grew. He wanted to have friends, go to school, and live a normal life like everyone else. He couldn't bear the burden of being extraordinary any longer.

Adam felt like he was living in a fishbowl, and he wanted out. He wanted to experience the world without being stared at, without being feared or worshipped. He wanted to be just like everyone else.

But the more he tried to suppress his powers, the more they grew. His powers were a part of him, and he couldn't deny them forever. Adam realized that being normal meant sacrificing a part of himself, and it wasn't worth it.

Instead, he decided to embrace his powers and use them for good. He started working with people who had similar abilities and found a community that accepted him for who he was. He realized that he didn't need to be normal to be happy, but he needed to be himself.

Adam learned that being extraordinary wasn't a curse, but a gift. It was up to him how he used his powers, and he chose to use them for the greater good. And with that, he finally found peace within himself.

Yes, there are some books in which the protagonist has the ability to temporarily obtain other people's powers, memories, or skills. Here are a few examples:

conversation.content: Give me a highly detailed story about a group of teenagers who play the game of truth or dare but  what they didn't know about is that if they fail to answer the truth or failed to do the dare they will be killed in a mysterious way

In the sleepy town of Willow's Creek, a group of six friends gathered in the old Martin House for an unforgettable sleepover. The group consisted of Alex, the kind-hearted jock; Natalie, the confident queen bee; Zoey, the quirky artist; Richard, the witty loner; Shane, the lovable goofball; and Mia, the brilliant introvert. All of them were seniors at Willow's Creek High School and wanted to create one final, memorable experience before their impending separation come graduation.

It was on this eerie autumn evening when the clouds loomed ominously in the full moon's stead, and the wind whispered secrets through the swaying trees. Zoey, inspired by the spooky atmosphere, suggested a friendly game of truth or dare. Everyone quickly chimed in, agreeing to this seemingly harmless idea. Unbeknownst to them, this simple game would forever change their lives in the most devastating way possible.

As they sat in a circle, with only the flickering light of a dying fire casting shadows onto their unaware faces, they began the game. At first, the questions and dares were innocent enough. They asked each other about secret crushes and dared each other to sing a song or do a funny dance. Laughter filled the room, as did the sense of camaraderie that had been the foundation of their friendship for all those years.

However, things took an unexpected turn when Richard dared Zoey to explore the dusty attic – a place the Martin family had forbidden them from venturing. Zoey, not one to back down from a challenge, sneaked up the creaky staircase, her curiosity piqued. In the attic, she discovered an antique Ouija board that bore the inscription, "Those who fail a truth or a dare shall face consequences most dire."

Zoey, captivated and eager to ignite some excitement, introduced the Ouija board to the circle of friends. Unaware of its ominous implications, they all placed their fingers on the planchette and asked if there were any spirits present who wished to participate in their game. The planchette swiftly moved to spell the word "Yes." Goosebumps covered their skins as they realized that this game may not be as innocent as they had anticipated.

Now, each question or dare was selected provocatively by the mysterious spirit in charge. The group's laughter had faded into silence, replaced by the anxiety instilled by the eerie Ouija board. Alex, unable to shake off the uncomfortable feeling, tried to answer his truth question dishonestly. As soon as his lie left his lips, the flame of the fire abruptly extinguished, plunging the room into darkness.

A spine-chilling scream filled the air as Alex's lifeless body collapsed onto the cold wooden floor, his eyes wide open in horror. Panic ensued as the friends tried to process what had just happened. Among the chaos, Mia, who had been quietly observing the situation, realized that the spirit was holding them captive, ensuring that the rules of the game were followed strictly.

With a heavy heart and trembling hands, the remaining friends chose to continue with the game, fearful of the same fate that had befallen Alex. Natalie faltered when faced with her dare, refusing to jump from the second-story window. Her heart-wrenching scream echoed through the house next, as she, too, perished under the grip of the enigmatic entity.

With each passing round, the atmosphere became heavier, more oppressive. The weight of their unspoken guilt weighed heavily on their chests. Richard, unable to withstand the pressure, admitted that he had cheated on his girlfriend. Failing to tell the whole truth, Richard was the next one to be silenced forever.

As the game continued, Shane was dared to spend the night in the nearby cemetery. Attempting to leave the house, he found that the doors and windows were inexplicably sealed shut. Unable to complete his dare, he met an agonizing end, much to the dismay of the remaining friends.

Now only Zoey and Mia remained, completely terrified and holding onto each other, praying for the nightmare to end. The spirit offered Mia the opportunity to be freed if she met one, final dare. With a determined breath, Mia accepted, intent on surviving the night.

Her dare was simple - to burn the Ouija board down, ensuring that it could never torment anyone ever again. Summoning courage she didn't know she possessed, Mia grabbed Zoey's trembling hand and searched for a lighter. Her heart was pounding like a jackhammer as she slowly approached the board and flicked the lighter.

Flames quickly danced over the cursed board, consuming it with an unbearable heat. As quickly as the fire began, the entity's grip on the house vanished. The silence following was both soothing and deafening. Zoey and Mia held each other close, tears streaming down their faces as they mourned those they'd lost.

Though their friendship would never be the same again, Zoey and Mia proved that hope and courage could vanquish even the strongest of evils. The haunting memories would never truly disappear, but the bond they forged in the face of darkness could withstand anything.

When she slowly and sensually wraps her legs around him, he doesn't suspect a thing. She begins to squeeze him really tight, to the point were it becomes difficult to breathe. He struggles to free himself, but all his attempts are futile. The dancer keeps squeezing him with her powerful thighs, while teasing him about the predicament. He passes out multiple time, only to wake up still trapped within her tight grasp. When the time is up, she decides to knock him out and leaves him, her job being done. (Embellish the story with many details)

The rain came down like bullets, turning the dark alleyways into swimming pools for the rats. He stepped out of the taxicab, splashing in the filthy water that was drowning the pavement. The driver barked the price at him, but it was barely audible over the orchestra of thunder and gunfire that filled the empty spaces between the crumbling buildings. He threw a few bills at the man; it didn't matter how much - this wasn't going to be his last stop tonight anyway. It never was.

The sign flickered above: "Nights of Delight," like a thousand degenerate dreams. He knew the place well, and if he'd still been with the force they might've caught on. But he'd been kicked out long ago like yesterday's coffee grounds. Maybe now he could afford a little vice - a little dimly-lit comfort in a world of cold steel and shadow.

He walked into the club with an air of determination, and as easily as putting on a hat, he made the place his own. He knew the owner well, but they didn't exchange a word. Instead, the owner nodded toward a door in the back of the room. That was it; that's all he came for.

Opening the door, he discovered the scent of the delicate perfume, and a vision that seemed a mirage through the fog of smoke and lies. She danced, her body moving like silk draped over a blade. This wasn't what he'd expected to find behind the door, but then again, he'd seen the best of people fade in the darkness like fading sunlight.

"You're late," she began, her voice like a whisper that stirred the velvet curtain around them.

He smirked. "Were you waiting long?"

She smiled slyly, a knowing glint in her eye. "Oh, I just started without you, Mr. Smith."

If that was even his name. Around these parts, names changed as often as the number of broken hearts. But hers was mentioned for a reason. A rumor of a dancer who could make a man forget his troubles, even for just a while. A dancer whose legs could wrap a man up in a cocoon that no worries, no pain, and no other temptations could penetrate. At least, not for the few moments he was trapped within her embrace.

They didn't banter much more before she began. A choreography of sensuality and desire unfurling before him. He watched her with a hunger that couldn't be sated by the sweat on her brow or the sound of her breath in his ear. Nothing would quench it, save for the dance.

Slowly, inevitably, she slid her svelte legs around him, just as a shadow creeps up on its prey. At first, he savored the feeling of her strong thighs wrapped around his torso, marveling at the force of femininity. He didn't know why he was targeted, and, at the moment, he didn't care.

But, when her grip tightened to the point where it was difficult to breathe, he began to panic, clashing with the darkness that enveloped her embrace. She whispered in his ear, "Now the real dance begins."

He tried to pull away, his panic rising with every strained gasp. "You don't have to do this. Let's make a deal!"

Her laughter was like poisoned honey, and her voice a sinister lullaby. "Oh, don't you know, Mr. Smith? My dance, my rules. Besides, I'm only keeping you... entertained."

He couldn't escape. Every desperate, fumbling attempt to loosen her grip was met with only tighter pressure. Every gasp for air was stolen away from him. He slipped in and out of consciousness, waking only to find himself still trapped between her muscular thighs, starting the cruel dance over again.

It went on for eternities, or perhaps just hours, but he knew it would end one way or another. As the darkness began to take hold again, he heard her final words, a promise or a curse, he didn't know which. "Time's up, Mr. Smith."

He was left unconscious on the cold, hard floor, and she stepped over him and back into the shadows that she called home. Her job was done, just like any other job in this sinful, heartless city. Each soul, each battered heart beating in time to the same haunting tune, the whisper of the blade on the flesh of innocence.

He would wake up later, gasping for air, wondering whether it was a nightmare or a fantasy. But he wouldn't remember her name, because in the end, names were only as important as the lies they told.

conversation.content: Write in polished language the psychology in sync with child narrator and third person narrator in novel a portrait of the artist as a young man

Embodying the evocative essence of childhood, the novel A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man captures the psychological landscape of a maturing artist. Through the transitional narrative, merging the consciousness of a child narrator with the discreet commentary of a third-person narrator, James Joyce elucidates the unfolding self-awareness and experiences of Stephen Dedalus.

In the initial stages of the novel, our young narrator presents the fragmented and impressionistic world seen from a child's drawing of memory - vivid, yet uncertain. Together, as readers and silent observers, we delve into the liminal space shared by the child narrator and the discreet, adult third-person narrator, joining together to form an eloquent, if ambiguous, reflection of reality. This duality of perception not only enriches the character's emotional resonance but also elevates the novel's psychological depth, inviting us to a nuanced understanding of a child's burgeoning consciousness.

Amidst the gentle, lyrical tales of youth and longing, there is an omnipresent, yet unobtrusive, cognizance of a child's deeply embedded fears and desires—the urge to belong and the simultaneous, conflicting urge for self-actualization. Through the harmonious interplay of the child and third-person narratives, we are privy to the internal battles waged within the psyche of a growing artist. The artful symbiosis of narratives creates a delicate portrayal of the Artist's struggle with identity—a nebulous and fluid concept that transcends the confines of social expectations and familial obligations.

As we traverse the winding path of Stephen's psychological journey, the child-like narrative of innocence transitions into the probing, contemplative voice of a young adult. The third-person narrator accompanies this transition, seamlessly melding into Stephen's newfound introspection. In this maturation of narrative, the fragmentation of Stephen's initial childhood recollections gives way to the clarity of his convictions as a budding artist. An insightful commentary on the nature of art and aesthetics takes life, encompassing both the naïve hopefulness of the child-narrator and the discerning eye of a reflective, experienced artist.

Embarking on a quest for self-discovery and understanding, we witness the evolving psychological landscape of the protagonist coupled with the harmonious interweaving of the dual narratives to create a portrait of the artist in its totality. The profound insight offered by the novel's psychology stands testament to its literary merit, as the novel transcends the mere evocation of a young man's life story, instead saturating the reader's psyche with the timeless essence of coming of age.

A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man invites an unspoken communion between the reader and the novel's dual narratives, drawing us into the multifaceted and compelling landscape of the human psyche. The evocative psychological insights granted through the intertwined perspectives of a child narrator and third-person narrator pave the path for an exploration into the very essence of individuality, artistry, and selfhood.

As a novel that fluidly explores the developing consciousness of the protagonist, A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man deftly employs dual narrative perspectives, melding the ebbs and flows of child and third-person narrators. Indeed, the psychology at work in James Joyce's seminal work is a testament to his masterful control of narrative form and psychological insight.

The child narrator's perspective is one rife with wonder, curiosity, and a certain naivete; it is a world in which every experience brims with evocative newness, and where even the mundane becomes magical. This narrator's voice is employed with great finesse in the opening chapters, as young Stephen Dedalus grapples with the intimacies of his family and school, attempting to navigate the tumultuous terrain of his social world. Through this wide-eyed lens, the reader is afforded a rare glimpse into the complex interplay of the human psyche, observing the myriad forces and influences shaping Stephen's character even as he retains an unworldly innocence.

In sync with this perspective, the third person narration offers a counterpoint that juxtaposes the introspective musings of the young artist with an impartial, omniscient wisdom. There is a near-constant oscillation between the intimacy of the first-person narrative and the broader sweep of the third-person narrator. What results is a rich tapestry of experience, as the reader is drawn into the intimate realm of Stephen's inner life while simultaneously being allowed to witness his growth and development from a distance.

The third-person narrator also sheds light on the social and political climate in Ireland, delineating the various religious, familial, and political influences acting upon Stephen throughout his adolescence. This voice assumes a more commanding presence as Stephen grows older, granting insight into the gradually shifting dynamics of power that define his experiences of self-discovery.

Intrinsic to the psychological trajectory of A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man is an underlying tension between these two narrative voices, with the child narrator gradually ceding control to the third person as Stephen progresses from infancy toward the precipice of adulthood. This transition, however, is not absolute; rather, it is interspersed with fleeting moments of childlike emotion and whimsy, imbuing the novel with a veritable whirlwind of emotion and sensation that captivates the reader.

Ultimately, the dual narrative perspectives at work within A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man serve to reinforce the novel's exploration of the nature of human consciousness and the ceaseless quest for self-definition. Through the confluence of the child and third-person narrators, Joyce generates a textually rich and psychologically nuanced portrait of a young man coming into his own, revealing the myriad ways in which an individual's internal and external worlds shape the contours of his soul.

conversation.content: напиши реферат про нарратив в кино

Нарратив в кино является важной составляющей любого фильма. Он определяет способ, в котором история будет рассказана зрителям, и дает возможность создателям фильма влиять на то, как зрители будут реагировать на сюжет, персонажей и тему фильма.

Одним из ключевых элементов нарратива является структура фильма. Обычно фильм делится на три акта - введение, развитие и финал. Введение знакомит зрителя с главными персонажами и сюжетом фильма. Развитие состоит из ряда событий, которые приводят к конфликту и высшей точке фильма. Финал разрешает конфликт и завершает историю.

Кроме структуры, нарратив включает в себя такие элементы, как персонажи, звук и визуальный язык. Персонажи являются главными двигателями сюжета и должны быть интересными и зрелищными, чтобы зритель мог сопереживать им и оставаться заинтересованным в том, что происходит на экране.

Звук и визуальный язык также играют важную роль в нарративе. Звуковое оформление включает в себя диалоги, звуковые эффекты и музыкальное оформление. Эти элементы могут подчеркнуть настроение и эмоциональную составляющую фильма.

Визуальный язык включает в себя кадры, цвет и освещение. Использование этих элементов может создать определенную атмосферу и помочь зрителю лучше понять историю.

В завершение можно сказать, что нарратив является ключевым элементом любого фильма, который определяет способ, в котором история будет рассказана зрительской аудитории. Элементы нарратива включают в себя структуру, персонажей, звук и визуальный язык, которые вместе с целью и тематикой фильма создают определенный настроение и эмоциональный ответ у зрителя.

Жанр является ключевым элементом в создании и продвижении фильма, поскольку он определяет аудиторию, которую фильм должен привлечь.

Один из наиболее известных жанров - драма, фильмы этого жанра зачастую описывают эмоциональный опыт персонажей или событий, которые касаются человеческой жизни. Драматические фильмы могут быть лиричными, эмоциональными, интеллектуальными или реалистическими, в зависимости от тематики.

Ещё один популярный жанр - комедия, здесь сюжет используется для создания приятного и веселого настроения. Комедии бывают разных типов - от пародий до исторических костюмных комедий. Комедии содержат взаимодействующие персонажей, множество юмористических элементов и ситуации, которые заставляют зрителей смеяться.

Другой популярный жанр - ужасы, эти фильмы нацелены на то, чтобы вызвать страх или ужас у зрителя. Фильмы этого жанра могут быть затаскивающими, жуткими или просто жутковатыми, зависит от того, какие элементы хоррора используются. Сюжеты ужастиков часто связаны с фантастическими и непонятными вещами, которые становятся угрозой для главных героев.

Также стоит отметить и другие жанры, такие как мелодрама, экшен, фантастика и триллеры. Каждый из этих жанров имеет свои уникальные характеристики, которые отличают их друг от друга.

Жанр - это важный показатель для зрителя, который показывает, что можно ожидать от фильма. Это определяет, насколько он может быть интересен рынку и какие ожидания у зрителей. Жанр - один из ключевых элементов фильма, который определяет его успех в кинематографической индустрии.
напиши текст про Майкла Коллинза

Майкл Коллинз - известный гитарист и автор песен, родившийся в Лондоне, Англия, в 1954 году. Он начал играть на гитаре в возрасте 14 лет и в течение нескольких лет играл в различных местных группах.

В 1976 году Коллинз получил свой первый большой успех, став гитаристом в группе "Genesis". С Коллинзом группа достигла своего наивысшего коммерческого успеха в 1980-х годах, когда он принял фронтменские обязанности после ухода Питера Гэбриэла. Коллинз написал и исполнил такие хиты как "Against All Odds", "In the Air Tonight" и "Another Day in Paradise".

После ухода из "Genesis" в 1996 году, Коллинз начал сольную карьеру, выпустив альбомы, которые стали хитами. В 1999 году его альбом "Tarzan" был номинирован на премию Грэмми за лучшую саундтрековую музыку.

Однако, в начале 2000-х годов, Коллинз объявил о своем выходе на пенсию, сославшись на проблемы со здоровьем. Он провел несколько операций на спине и прекратил выступать на сцене. Однако, Коллинз продолжил писать и записывать музыку и выпустил несколько альбомов на CD.

За свою карьеру Майкл Коллинз продал более 150 миллионов копий своих альбомов со "Genesis" и как сольный музыкант. Он также был номинирован на премию Грэмми 14 раз и выиграл пять из них.

Коллинз также известен своей работой в социальном секторе, особенно через свою благотворительную организацию "Little Dreams Foundation". Он уделяет значительную часть своего времени и усилий помощи молодым талантам в музыке, спорте и искусстве.

В заключение можно сказать, что Майкл Коллинз - это знаменитый гитарист, автор песен и благотворительный деятель, который создал знаковые хиты, которые продолжают пользоваться любовью поклонников по всему миру. Его вклад в культуру музыки является важным элементом ее развития и продолжает вдохновлять других музыкантов.
Напиши про нарративный анализ

Нарративный анализ - это метод исследования, который используется для анализа текста, рассказа или любой другой формы выражения, чтобы понять, какие значения и смыслы относятся к этому тексту. Он выходит за рамки простого обоснования сюжета или содержания и позволяет исследовать стиль и язык текста, оценить намерения автора и создателя, понять контекст создания работы.

Основной целью нарративного анализа является раскрытие смысла текста, который иначе мог бы остаться незамеченным или не понятым. Для достижения этой цели анализируется структура текста, мотивационные факторы, использование языка и другие элементы.

Структура текста является одним из важных элементов нарративного анализа. Аналитик может исследовать, как события, персонажи или темы связаны друг с другом и развиваются в течение времени. Обращая внимание на возникающие конфликты - это позволяет оценить, как исследуемый текст строится и как герои взаимодействуют в рамках развития истории.

Важным аспектом является также использование языка и выражение авторских намерений. Достигается это благодаря анализу используемых выражений, метафор и других стилевых средств, а также используемых знаков, символов и аллегорий. Анализ нарратива мог бы рассматриваться по отношению к идентификации авторских намерений и модификации текста.

В целом, нарративный анализ предоставляет исследователю больше информации о том, что может прямо или косвенно сказываться на создании текста. Позволяет получить ответы на вопросы, связанные с использованием стилевых приемов, соотношением персонажей и действий, контекстом создания работы. Подход может использоваться для анализа различных форм искусства, а также для исследования социальных вопросов и явлений.

Title: Exploring the Intricacies of Gendered Violence in Nawal El Saadawi's "Woman at Point Zero"

Abstract:

This erudite exploration of Nawal El Saadawi's seminal novel, "Woman at Point Zero," delves into the complexities and intricacies of gendered violence perpetrated by members of the same sex. By employing apt theoretical frameworks, such as feminist theory, postcolonial theory, and psychoanalytic theory, this comprehensive analysis endeavors to unveil the variegated dimensions of same-gender violence expounded upon in El Saadawi's text. Drawing from the scholarly works of prominent critics such as Judith Butler, Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak, and Sigmund Freud, this paper articulates, in luminous language and academic rigor, the profound implications of El Saadawi's exposition of gendered violence.

Keywords: Nawal El Saadawi, Woman at Point Zero, gendered violence, feminist theory, postcolonial theory, psychoanalysis

I. Introduction

A confluence of captivating notions and perspicacious perspectives amalgamate in Nawal El Saadawi's "Woman at Point Zero," a novel that engenders a fecund ground for critical analysis in the realm of gender studies. In particular, the text elucidates the reality of violence perpetrated by individuals against members of their own gender. Through an examination of compelling theoretical frameworks, including feminist theory, postcolonial theory, and psychoanalytic theory, this paper seeks to excavate the multifaceted dimensions of same-gender violence as presented in El Saadawi's novel.

II. Feminist Theory: A Framework for Understanding Same-Gender Violence

Judith Butler's performativity theory elucidates the idea that gender is socially constructed, and the omnipresent, regulated repetition of gendered behaviors assiduously entrenches such expectation within an individual's psyche. As Butler (1990) unequivocally states, "gender is performatively constituted through the acts by which it is presupposed" (p. 34). Consequently, one may deduce that the genesis of same-gender violence can be located in the internalization of gender norms.

El Saadawi's portrayal of the protagonist Firdaus exposes the reader to the horrific milieu of entrenched gender expectations, which are internalized by women themselves. For instance, the egregious female genital mutilation that Firdaus endures is inflicted by her own aunt. This act of violence, engendered by the desire to uphold societal gender expectations, demonstrates the extent to which women are indoctrinated to inflict harm upon one another in a bid to adhere to the patriarchal order. Concomitantly, El Saadawi's novel illuminates the oppressive institutionalization of gender norms in society; a notion succinctly echoed by feminist scholars such as Simone de Beauvoir (1949), who posits that "one is not born, but rather becomes, a woman" (p. 295).

III. Postcolonial Theory: The Intersectionality of Oppression and Gendered Violence

Within the purview of postcolonial theory, the concept of intersectionality, as expounded upon by Kimberlé Crenshaw, provides valuable insight into the chimerical relationship between transcultural influence and gendered violence. The imposition of Western gender norms upon colonized regions often exacerbates the objectification and oppression of women within such societies. According to Spivak (1994), the subaltern "cannot speak" because their "subject position is understood through a relation of power" (p. 104). Essentially, El Saadawi's protagonist Firdaus can be perceived as a subaltern figure who struggles with both gendered violence and her inability to voice her suffering. It is through her encounter with violence that she ultimately finds her voice and gains agency.

IV. Psychoanalytic Theory: The Role of the Unconscious in Same-Gender Violence

The incorporation of Sigmund Freud's psychoanalytic theory expounds upon the unconscious impetuses that propel individuals to perpetrate violence against members of their own gender. Elucidating the relationship between the three components of the psyche - the id, ego, and superego - Freud (1917) postulates that such intrapsychic conflicts may manifest themselves in the form of aggression. For instance, the female characters in El Saadawi's novel harbor feelings of resentment against the societal expectations imposed upon them. These suppressed emotions culminate in bursts of aggression, which are displaced onto other women in the narrative. This reconfiguration of internalized discontent and frustration elucidates the psychological underpinnings of same-gendered violence in the novel.

V. Conclusion

By adroitly weaving together feminist theory, postcolonial theory, and psychoanalytic theory, this erudite investigation into Nawal El Saadawi's "Woman at Point Zero" sheds light upon the manifold dimensions of same-gender violence that pervade the text. The application of these theoretical frameworks assist in the extrapolation of a more nuanced understanding of the societal, cultural, and psychological factors that give rise to intragender violence in El Saadawi's novel, and serves to accentuate the profound implications of the author's portrayal of gendered violence.

References:

Beauvoir, S. de. (1949). The Second Sex. Random House.

Butler, J. (1990). Gender Trouble: Feminism and the Subversion of Identity. Routledge.

Freud, S. (1917). Mourning and Melancholia. Standard Edition of the Complete Psychological Works of Sigmund Freud; translated by Strachey, J. Hogarth Press.

Spivak, G. C. (1994). Can the Subaltern Speak? In P. Williams and L. Chrisman (Eds.), Colonial Discourse and Postcolonial Theory: A Reader (pp. 66-111). Harvester Wheatsheaf.

Analyze the following:

In 2E 896, a noble warrior-king named Tiber Septim rose from the turmoil of the civil wars that consumed the continent of Tamriel and proclaimed himself Emperor. Many opposed his claim and were crushed beneath his might like sputtering sparks of flame. The year after his conquest, when Septim was crowned first Emperor of Tamriel, he declared also the beginning of a new era, the third era of Tamriel. But this is all ancient history to you.

You were born in 3E 375, during the reign of the twenty-first Emperor of Tamriel, Uriel Septim VII. The civilisation that Tiber Septim forced onto the subjects of his Empire has nearly fallen: as The Elder Scrolls predicted, the bloody wheel has nearly turned all the way back to anarchy. Some call it the whim of Jephre the Storyteller who crafts fate for his divine amusement. Others say that the unworthy heirs of Tiber allowed their vassal kings too much liberty or lacked their ancestors' military genius. A few look to the character of the people of the Arena of Tamriel and remark that no one could create a lasting empire in such a place -- Tiber must have had supernatural aid to accomplish what he did. Such theorising is best left to the Scrollkeepers of the Imperial City or the Psijics of the Isle of Artaeum. Tamriel is what it is.

The current Emperor is no stranger to you. You have helped him in the past, and know he considers you a loyal subject, perhaps even a friend. Trust is a hard prize to win from Uriel Septim. He trusted his last Imperial Battlemage, the power-mad Jagar Tharn, and it nearly destroyed him. His current Imperial Battlemage, Ocato of Firsthold, long of the Elder Council, has alone earned the position of the Emperor's confidante and chief advisor.

When the Emperor summoned you to his audience chamber, you were not surprised that he asked you to arrive after midnight. You were accustomed to seeing the Emperor at unusual hours. Sometimes it seemed that, to the Emperor, you were an unusually crafted weapon to be drawn in secrecy, away from the inquisitive eyes of the official court. A trusted guard escorted you down the gilded marble halls of the Imperial Palace to the Emperor's audience chamber. Along the way, you passed ancient tapestries and sculpture acquired by Tiber Septim or one of his equally avaricious descendants.

Uriel Septim greeted you formally, in utter darkness, as Ocato lit a single candle, emanating the barest illumination. This was to be an unusually surreptitious meeting, even for the cautious Uriel Septim.

"Please excuse the gloom," he began, with a solemnity that you had never heard before from him, "but none may know of our meeting. The nature of my trouble is darker still. Its subject is King Lysandus of Daggerfall, a man who died over a year ago, honourably, on the field of battle."

You started to respond, but were silenced. It was peculiar of the Emperor not to allow you any questions or comments. He almost seemed to be afraid of too much inquiry into this particular affair.

Without pause, the Emperor continued. "He was as great and as loyal a subject, ally, and friend to me as you are. I did grieve for him ... but I now hear his spirit will not rest. It haunts his former kingdom crying for revenge. I do not know why such a good and loyal man would be so cursed, but perhaps you could find the reason. You could close the marble jaws of Oblivion and put his soul to peace. I ask this of you as your Emperor, and also as your friend."

"I have one other lesser request. Several years ago, I sent a letter to Lysandus' Queen Mynisera. She now informs me that she never received it. The message was of a ... sentimental and personal nature. If you would find the letter, and destroy it, I would be most relieved."

The letter is more important than that, you remember instinctively thinking. But again, you were not given leave to ask any questions. The Emperor's dismissal was friendly, but absolute: "Now, my champion, rest well tonight, for tomorrow you sail for the kingdom of Daggerfall."

You packed lightly, for you understood the nature of the voyage ahead. The Emperor meant to send you on a small, anonymous sailing craft down the Yrinthi River to the Bjoulsae River, and from there across Iliac Bay to Daggerfall. All three bodies of water, the Yrinthi, the Bjoulsae, and Iliac Bay, were notoriously infested with pirates, and any ostentatiously-decorated craft would need to be conspicuously well-defended.

Your voyage was uneventful, which made the weeks of travel to the Iliac Bay seem even longer. You still had a thousand questions about the meaning of your mission: how were you to exorcise the spirit of King Lysandus, what was the significance of the Emperor's letter, and where that letter might be. Recognising the futility of pondering these unanswerable thoughts, you concentrated instead on recalling all you knew of Daggerfall and the Iliac Bay area.

You knew of the war that had claimed Lysandus. Called the War of Betony, it was an internecine struggle between the Kingdom of Daggerfall and the Kingdom of Sentinel. The battle was over a small, but politically significant, island at the western edge of the Bay, near the Abecean Sea. At the final battle of the war, the bloody Battle of Cryngaine Field, both kings were killed. In Sentinel, the king's widow, Akorithi, took the throne, regent until her children reached their majority. In Daggerfall, Lysandus was succeeded by his son, Gothryd. But Daggerfall won the war and possession of the island of Betony.

Gothryd's first act as king was to make official peace with Sentinel, and to marry Princess Aubk-i of Sentinel as a bond. You do not know whether this union has proven wise.

The third major power in the Iliac Bay, besides Daggerfall and Sentinel, is the Kingdom of Wayrest, ruled by elderly King Eadwyre and his wife. She was the legendary former Queen of Mournhold, Barenziah. Both have children of nearly the same age from previous marriages, and though you do not know the particulars, you recall hearing rumours that there exists a dispute over the succession. It would certainly be worth yoru while to take a trip to Wayrest. It is said to be a kingdom of great treasures, where the merchant classes have made their land rich by trade.

Your ship sailed past the ancient stone walls of Wayrest, and the Bjoulsae widened into the brilliant expanse of the Iliac Bay. Your eyes lifted from the water to the sky. To the west: utter darkness -- clouds boiling with fierce intensity obliterated the sun. You did not know how soon the storm would arrive, and you considered sailing back to the protected harbour of Wayrest. But, Wayrest's docks were not cheap; the merchants could charge whatever they wished to travellers fleeing from pirates or traders.

Anticlere was not far up the coast, and there were bound to be other small fishing villages where you could dock. It was hard to measure the distance to the storm -- perhaps it was out in the Abecean Sea and would dissipate before it crossed the Bay.

Unfortunately, the rain began a few miles west of the Isle of Balfiera. Soon it was so dark you could hardly see your boat. But you could feel it, grinding and cracking every time a wave struck its side. The water had darkened to a blackish violet. Your imagination was suddenly filled with fables of the monstrous creatures that lurked beneath Iliac Bay: weird tentacled beings, women with the bodies of eels, flesh-eating fish....

You pushed such fantasies away, and concentrated on the present danger. The rain came out of the darkness like an endless barrage of spears. The sound of it merged with the crashing of the waves, the splintering of your boat, and the high-pitched howl of the wind. You were becoming deaf as well as blind. You numbly steered the ship in the direction that you hoped was north.

Your last thoughts were directed on an ink black shape, rising ahead of you in the deep gray sky -- was it the side of a cliff or a darker fury of the storm? A blast of water rushed over the side of the ship, carrying you over. As you plunged into the dark and foaming bay, you saw your ship dive beneath the surface as if in imitation, and something struck your head.

You came very near to death, but by sheer willpower you won the struggle against the vortex beneath the sea. The storm had intensified to an unnatural tempest, like a living thing at the command of a maleficent master. With desperate, flailing hands, you gripped an outcropping of rock and slowly, painfully, pulled yourself toward the cliff's edge. The waves crashed against the stone wall, cracking the very surface of the precipice. Stones jarred loose from the cliff and became deadly projectiles. As the entire cliff face began to slough into the sea, carrying you with it, you saw the small cavern opening. You fell into the shelter.

Your eyes were adjusting to the cave's gloom when you heard the blast behind you. For a second you panicked. You were buried alive! Then you saw the tunnel -- your only way out.

Regular urban pests are not worth mentioning. They are usually more frightened of adventurers than vice versa. There exist, however, giant varieties that are the sharks of their swamps and sewers. Their strength lies in their ferocity, the size of their packs, and the virulence of the disease transmitted by their bites. A seasoned, well-armoured adventurer can pass through swarms of the little beasts in relative safety, but underestimating their brute cunning can be the last mistake that the less experienced will ever make.

Imps
The winged Imps have mysterious origins. Some say that they are little fiends from Oblivion, servants of the great Daedra Princes that have been sent to Tamriel as nuisances or in some darker mission. Others say that they are like the Atronachs or golems, creatures created from magicka as familiars or companions to powerful sorcerers. The truth may be that both theories are correct, or that Imps are something else entirely. Whatever their history, Imps are mischievous creatures, capable of casting minor but painful spells of pure magicka. They are certainly intelligent and speak their own language, and they are crafty enough that they know when to fight and when to flee.

Spriggans
Luckily for adventurers, these strange woodland fairykin are shy and reclusive, for they make very dangerous enemies. The old Nordic tales tell of the immortal Spriggan, who grow larger and mightier every time they fall. While in actuality Spriggans are not immortal, they are virtually impossible to kill.

Even if they are struck down, they will regenerate and arise to fight again. And the legend of the Spriggan growing larger and more powerful in each incarnation is indeed true.

Lycanthropes
These cursed creatures are men by day, completely indistinguishable from "normal" men, and savage half-beast predators when the moon is full. At least two lycanthropes are common to the Iliac Bay environs: the werewolf and the wereboar. The werewolf is only found in the woodlands of High Rock and rarely in the jungles of Hammerfell, but the wereboar is found everywhere, and is the more fearsome opponent. Neither seems to be capable of a thought beyond bloodlust, and both are impervious to common weaponry. Their claws are keen as razors and are somehow capable of transmitting the dreaded lycanthropy to those it strikes. While lycanthropy is a relatively simple disease for most temples to treat, few who survive a wereboar attack are likely to do more than be thankful and rest for several days. 'Tis ironic to count your blessings when you have just been cursed.

Orcs
From a distance, an orc may resemble a large, squat, muscular man -- before the tusks become evident, and the green skin and the piggish eyes are seen. Usually, when a viewer is that close to an Orc, he or she is not taking notes about the details. Orcs are among the most common encounters around the Iliac Bay, particularly around the southern half of the Wrothgarian Mountains. They are a consistently savage group, ready for a fight no matter the odds. Some rather eccentric researchers have suggested that the Orcs have a culture as ancient and sophisticated as ours, and that their seeming mindless barbarity is somehow related to rites of passage or tests of courage. It is highly likely that these researchers have never felt the sting of an orc captain's barbed axe.

Slaughterfishes
One of nature's most adaptable predators is the Slaughterfish of the Iliac Bay. Averaging six feet in length, with thousands of poisonous needlethin teeth, the Slaughterfish have infested practically every large body of water in the region. Unlucky swimmers have found that even deep inland lakes and underground rivers hide deadly schools. Slaughterfish are attracted to the taste of bloody water, so injured adventurers are advised to bathe only in small pools of water.

Centaurs
Centaurs are ancient and mysterious creatures, alternately worshipped and despised. Legends of their exploits range from the epic to the pornographic, perhaps for no better reason than that hey have varied personalities. The Council of Artaeum have called the Centaurs "true followers of the Old Ways" of Tamriel, referring to the complex system of ancestor worship that Artaeum itself espouses. All that one can certainly say about Centaurs is that in battle, there are few who are equal.

Harpies
One of the great tragic stories told in northern Hammerfell is of the group of cruel and beautiful witches who were transformed (or transformed themselves, the legend is somewhat murky) into hideous, deranged half-breed Harpies. Whatever the truth is behind the legend, the Harpies are a true threat to life and commerce along the Iliac Bay. They nest in abandoned ruins, mating with and then destroying the unfortunate human males they capture. While their maniacal nature makes them somewhat less-than-brilliant tacticians, their sharp talons and frenzied behaviour often force kingdoms to abandon lands to their use. Still, some say that the Harpies have some knowledge passed on to them from their human foremothers: knowledge they may give, but not freely.

Dreughs
Another of the so-called cursed races of Tamriel, the Dreughs are said to be the remnants of a once-great civilisation that flourished in the Iliac Bay long before the 1st Era. Though they have some humanoid characteristics, it is hard to give credence to the legend when one views the tentacles and the claws of the misshapen beasts. There is certain evidence that the Dreughs may have amphibian qualities, for they can be found in waterways far inland from their bayside origins. It is unlikely that the creatures themselves will offer insight to their origins, for Dreughs are violently hostile to all who invade their watery domain.

Daedra
The peasants have colourful terms for Daedra: fiends, unclean spirits, the evil ones, the Dark Princes, the gods of torment, the infernal ones, and, most commonly, demons. Those who wish to understand or battle these nightmarish beings, rather than live in fear, prefer the more circumspect term, Daedra. It is nearly impossible to say anything definitive about Daedra, despite thousands of years of scholarship devoted to their nature. Their reputation as cruel, amoral geniuses of destruction seems to be mostly deserved, but if they are true evil, our definition of evil may need revision to include the complexity of their natures. Daedra appear to have a well-organized hierarchy, and the ones found in our world are doubtless the weakest of the lot. Of course, the Fire Daedra, the Frost Daedra, the Seducer, or the Daedra Lord are among the most dangerous creatures in Tamriel, but there is certainly something greater out there in the world they call Oblivion. Perhaps we are already doomed to fall beneath their fire.

Vampires
Cruel, cunning, and immortal predators, vampires hunt the night, sometimes singly, sometimes in packs. Their powers and strengths are certainly the stuff of legends -- and there are said to be creatures called Vampire Ancients who are to Vampires as Vampires are to common man. Vampires are virtually immune to physical harm and are capable of casting a variety of powerful spells, not the least of which curses the victim with the dread disease vampirism. Like lycanthropy, vampirism can be easily cured in its early stages, but there is no known cure for undeath besides death itself. Probably, the most horrifying things about Vampires is their normalcy: you can never tell if someone is a Vampire until you feel the fangs at your neck. To what degree they have taken advantage of this and infiltrated human society is best left unimagined.

Dragons
The fairly common dragonling is a worthy opponent for any adventurer. It is capable of casting a number of powerful spells and healing itself in combat. Those who speak their language tell us that beneath a veneer of maddening riddles and non sequiturs are minds of great wisdom. Despite all their merits, dragonlings are less grand than their lineage would suggest. Explorers, sages, and archivists have argued for centuries over whether the great dragons of legends still live, if in fact they ever existed. The people of the Alik'r Desert insist that their vast plain of sand is home to a multitude of the Great Wyrms. Granting the nomads their propensity for tall tales, if there were a forsaken land where the great Dragons still fly undisturbed, it would indeed be the Alik'r Desert.

"Последний мир" – роман австрийского писателя Кристофа Рансмайра, впервые опубликован в 1988 году. Хронотоп этого произведения является сложным, множественным и глубоко взаимосвязанным миром античного города Томи, мифологических сюжетов из поэзии Овидия и современного мира автора. Рассмотрим основные компоненты хронотопа романа.

1. Античный город Томи – место ссылки знаменитого римского поэта Овидия, куда он был отправлен императором Августом за "грех", совершенный его произведением. Томи расположен на западном побережье Черного моря (современные территории Румынии) и является символом границы известного мира, местом контакта между историей и мифологией. Этот город-граница основной сюжетной линии романа отражает яркие контрасты античной культуры с мифической реальностью, а также с собственным внутренним растрепанным миром главного героя.

2. Сюжеты и образы из поэтического наследия Овидия, особенно из его знаменитого произведения "Метаморфозы", становятся важным элементом хронотопа. В романе присутствуют многочисленные отсылки к мифам о Деянирах и Нессе, Фетоне и Его сестрах, Нарциссе и Эхо. Эти мифы активно переплетаются с сюжетом романа и эпизодами из жизни Овидия в Томи, создавая особую атмосферу потусторонности и метаморфоз, столь символичную для общей концепции произведения.

3. Современный мир автора также присутствует в хронотопе романа как временна́я и пространственна́я панорама, сопоставимая с образами античного Томи и мифических сюжетов. Это проявляется в таких моментах, как встреча главного героя с современными исследователями Овидия или рефлексии относительно власти, творчества и политической репрессии. В этом контексте роман является аллегорией, насыщенной идеями о непрерывности истории, множественности миров и, одновременно, их хрупкости перед лицом тотальной власти.

Таким образом, хронотоп романа "Последний мир" представляет собой сложную переплетение античной реальности и мифических сюжетов, осветлённых сквозь призму современной рефлексии и проникнутых темой метаморфоз и изменений.

《罪与罚》是俄国作家陀思妥耶夫斯基创作的小说，于1866年首次发表。这是一部关于犯罪和良心的经典小说，也是陀思妥耶夫斯基最著名的作品之一。

小说讲述了一个叫罗迪昂·罗斯季科的年轻人因为贫困而犯罪，杀死了一个老妇人和她的妹妹。虽然他设法逃脱了惩罚，但是内疚和良心的谴责不断折磨着他。他交了一个好朋友叶甫盖尼·洛夫洛夫的朋友索菲娅，将所有财产给了她的家人，试图补偿他的罪恶。罗斯季科通过自我惩罚和受苦来赎回自己的罪孽，而最终，他意识到他不能通过这种方式得到救赎。他在警方的监视下，遇到了一个叫马尔梅洛杜夫的罪犯，后者同样因为自己犯下的罪孽而经受了痛苦。最终，罗斯季科决定向警方自首并接受惩罚，同时，他也帮助了其他监狱中的犯人。

《罪与罚》被视为一部具有社会和心理内涵的重要作品，探讨了罪恶、良知和救赎的问题。小说深入探索了罪犯的内心，以及罪犯和社会之间的复杂关系，表达出作者对人性的理解和担忧。
罗迪昂·罗斯季科有哪些具体的心理活动

罗迪昂·罗斯季科是《罪与罚》的主人公，他在小说中经历了许多复杂的心理活动。

1. 内疚和惧怕：罗迪昂在实施犯罪的过程中，感到了巨大的内疚和惧怕。他知道自己做了一件不道德的事情，但是无法停止。

2. 迷茫和矛盾：罗迪昂做出犯罪行为后，他的内心变得迷茫和矛盾。他不知道如何面对自己的罪行和内心的恐惧感。

3. 愧疚和苦恼：尽管罗迪昂没有被警方抓住，但是他的内心始终感到愧疚和苦恼。无论他如何努力自欺欺人，都无法让自己心安理得。

4. 自卑和社交障碍：罗迪昂自卑并且缺乏自信。他在社交场合中感到很不自在，而且与人交流受到了阻碍。

5. 救赎和改变：最终，罗迪昂决定通过向警方自首来实现自己的救赎和改变。他发现自己无法逃避内心的惩罚和良心的谴责，并通过这种方式来面对和解决自己的罪孽。
罪与罚的主角不是拉斯科尔尼科夫吗
主角是罗迪昂·罗斯季科，而非拉斯科尔尼科夫。拉斯科尔尼科夫是小说的另一个角色，他是一名知识分子，对社会的不公和不道德感到不满，并因为同情罗斯季科而与他成为朋友。拉斯科尔尼科夫在小说中的作用是帮助读者了解罗斯季科的内在世界，反映社会的现实，扮演一位道德价值观的代表。但主角是罗迪昂。
拉斯科尔尼科夫有哪些具体的心理活动

拉斯科尔尼科夫是《罪与罚》中的一位复杂人物，他的精神世界和思想在小说中占据了极其重要的地位。

1. 内心矛盾和崇高理想：拉斯科尔尼科夫一方面自认为有着崇高的思想和理想，但另一方面，又深感自己的无力和无能，这种内心的矛盾使他陷入了迷茫。

2. 自责和自我谴责：对于自己的思想、言论和行为，拉斯科尔尼科夫常常过于自责并自我谴责，尤其是在发现罗迪昂犯罪之后，他的内心被严重地挑战。

3. 激动和憎恨：尽管拉斯科尔尼科夫有着对人道和道德的追求和理想，但在面对某些人或状况时，他的内心也会产生激动和憎恨的情绪。

4. 安逸和幸福：拉斯科尔尼科夫也有一种单纯的希望安逸和幸福的情感，而这种情感却在现实中往往不能够得到满足。

5. 绝望和自我毁灭：在面对社会的不公、罪恶和腐败的时候，拉斯科尔尼科夫也曾经产生过绝望的情绪，并想过自我毁灭的念头。他的思想和精神领域是《罪与罚》组成部分之一，并反映了小说中社会和人性的复杂性和广阔性。
拉斯科尔尼科夫 是不是把人分为 特殊的人和普通的人

是的，拉斯科尔尼科夫在小说中把人分为两类，即“特殊的人”和“普通的人”。他认为，一些人具有超人的能力和感觉，可以透过现象看到本质，思考出超越常人的思想和真理。这些人是特殊的人，是领导人和创造者。而另一些人则是普通的人，他们只追求生存和享乐，缺乏思想和道德追求。对于拉斯科尔尼科夫来说，罗迪昂是一位特殊的人，具有解救民众的能力，而其他人则是普通的人，缺乏道德追求。他认为，特殊的人应该有更高的责任和担当，并为社会做出更多的贡献。通过这种方式，拉斯科尔尼科夫试图表达自己对于精神世界和社会阶级的认识、感知和观点。
我在别的资料里边看到叶甫盖尼·帕夫洛维奇·拉斯科尔尼科夫才是罪与罚的主角

叶甫盖尼·帕夫洛维奇·拉斯科尔尼科夫是《罪与罚》中的一个重要角色，但不是主角。主角是罗迪昂·罗斯季科，他是小说中的犯罪者和救赎者，整个故事主要讲述了他的犯罪、内心的挣扎以及最终的自我救赎。而拉斯科尔尼科夫则是一个知识分子，对于社会的不公和不道德感到不满，他对罗斯季科的行为和思想进行了探究和分析，扮演了相当重要的角色。但拉斯科尔尼科夫并没有像罗斯季科那样经历罪恶、后悔和救赎的过程，他的角色主要是在整个故事中扮演了一个思想启示和社会反思的作用。因此，虽然拉斯科尔尼科夫是非常重要的角色，但他并不是《罪与罚》的主角。
你再思考一下，我在大料资料里边都看到拉斯科尔尼科夫是主角

非常抱歉，我的前面回答有些错误。有些人把拉斯科尔尼科夫视为该小说的主角，尽管罗迪昂·罗斯季科也是该小说的极为重要的角色。拉斯科尔尼科夫是一个知识分子，他对社会问题进行了深刻的思考和反思，这使得他的思想和精神状态占据了小说的很大部分。同时，罗迪昂·罗斯季科也是小说的重要角色之一，他的故事和成长展示了小说中的许多主题，包括罪恶、后悔和救赎。因此，可以说，这两个角色都在小说的故事线中扮演了非常重要的角色，没有一个具有明显的优先权。
你基于哪些地方判断认为两个角色没有明显的优先权

我是基于以下几点的考虑：

1. 故事结构上，小说轮流关注罗迪昂和拉斯科尔尼科夫的生活和内心，并为他们的情感和思想建立复杂、细致的观察和分析。

2. 小说刻画角色的方式上，陀思妥耶夫斯基不仅通过罗迪昂和拉斯科尔尼科夫的发言和行动，还通过对他们内心的渲染和描写来打造两个受众皆可理解的人格。

3. 故事中罗迪昂和拉斯科尔尼科夫的形象都极具象征性，他们代表着两种不同的思想方式和生活态度，都对小说中的重大主题产生了深远的影响。

基于以上诸多方面的因素，我认为罗迪昂和拉斯科尔尼科夫两位角色在小说中都发挥着重要角色，并且这两个角色之间没有明显的优先权。
拉斯科尔尼科夫是不是坏人

拉斯科尔尼科夫在《罪与罚》中并不是一个坏人，而是一个复杂的角色。他是一位巨大的知识分子，极为理性和严肃，思想意识比较高。他在小说中起到了揭示社会现实和人性弊病、探究道德观念、内省人生哲学等诸多作用，并且是整个故事的中心人物之一。尽管拉斯科尔尼科夫曾被描述为自负、狂妄和自私，但他的言行和行为都显示出他具有思想和理念上的高尚，尤其是对于罗迪昂和社会问题的关注，更是极具创造性和远见。因此，从整个人物形象和故事线角度来看，无法将拉斯科尔尼科夫单纯地定义为一个坏人。

Fyodor Dostoevsky’s novel “Crime and Punishment” portrays the psychological journey of Rodion Raskolnikov, a young man who believes in his own superiority and tries to prove it by committing a murder. Raskolnikov’s true tragedy lies in his inability to reconcile his theories of the “extraordinary man,” his own guilt, and his belief in redemption.

Raskolnikov’s theory of the extraordinary man asserts that certain individuals are above the law and morality and have the right to commit crimes if they are beneficial to society. However, his crime did not have the intended consequences, and the guilt and torment that follow consume him. Raskolnikov’s isolation and inner turmoil stem from him feeling like he is neither “ordinary” nor “extraordinary” but falls somewhere in between.

What further complicates Raskolnikov’s tragedy is his desperate search for redemption. Despite his belief in the extraordinary, he is ultimately unable to escape the consequences of his actions. Fyodor Dostoevsky’s novel “Crime and Punishment” portrays the psychological journey of Rodion Raskolnikov, a young man who believes in his own superiority and tries to prove it by committing a murder. The novel shows the tragedy that arises from Raskolnikov’s inability to reconcile his theories of the “extraordinary man,” his guilt, and his quest for redemption.

Raskolnikov’s theory of the extraordinary man asserts that certain individuals are above the law and morality and have the right to commit crimes if they are beneficial to society. However, his crime did not have the intended consequences, and the guilt and torment that follow consume him. Raskolnikov’s isolation and inner turmoil stem from him feeling like he is neither “ordinary” nor “extraordinary” but falls somewhere in between. 

Despite the theories Raskolnikov holds, he is still, fundamentally, a humane person. He helps the Marmeladov family and, despite knowing her only briefly, he helps a girl in need. Yet, Raskolnikov is also prideful and driven by his belief in the extraordinary man. His mistake is in thinking he can surpass the fundamental law of not taking someone's life, no matter the justification.

What further complicates Raskolnikov’s tragedy is his desperate search for redemption. Despite his belief in the extraordinary, he is ultimately unable to escape the consequences of his actions. His guilt weighs heavily on him, leading to a physical and psychological breakdown. He is unable to forgive himself, but he also understands that the only way to move forward from his guilt is to confess and accept his punishment.

Moreover, Raskolnikov’s struggle for redemption is further intensified by his relationships with other characters. His love for Sonya is a source of hope for him, but he cannot bear to burden her with his guilt. Raskolnikov’s sister Dounia, on the other hand, represents the morality he has betrayed. Her forgiveness is strained and difficult to attain, further complicating his path to redemption.

The most significant tragedy for the protagonist is the struggle of his thoughts and feelings, an internal struggle. Rethinking values, principles of ideals can help to cope with this struggle. Pangs of conscience are heavy for any person, and if they worry about such a global crime as murder, then what Raskolnikov felt was an immensely heavy burden, which he coped with not only on his own but also with the help of his friends and relatives. The novel shows that true redemption comes from personal accountability and owning up to one’s actions, rather than from attempting to escape punishment or rationalizing one’s behavior. Raskolnikov’s journey is a cautionary tale about the dangers of hubris and the importance of moral responsibility. The lesson to be learnt is that no one, no matter how intelligent or superior, is above the law and morality, and no act of violence and harm can be justified.

conversation.content: Philosophy and problems raised by Arkady and Boris Strugatsky in the book "Dead Mountaineer's Hotel"

"Dead Mountaineer's Hotel" is a mystery sci-fi novel written by the Strugatsky brothers, Arkady and Boris Strugatsky. The story revolves around Inspector Glebsky, who is called to the titular hotel to investigate a report of suspicious activity. As the plot unravels, Glebsky discovers that not all of the hotel's guests are human, raising questions on morality, identity, and the nature of existence.

The philosophical problems and themes raised in the novel can be discussed using the following aspects:

1. Existentialism: As Glebsky unravels the mystery surrounding the hotel guests, he is forced to confront questions related to his own existence, purpose, and the nature of the universe. The presence of extraterrestrial beings challenges his understanding of reality and forces him to reconsider his preconceived notions about life.

2. Morality: The novel raises philosophical questions about moral relativism and the concept of good vs. evil. The alien guests have their own moral code, which conflicts with human norms. Glebsky's struggle to understand the alien's values and motivations makes readers question their own beliefs on morality and what constitutes right and wrong.

3. The concept of the "Other": The novel questions how we perceive and interact with those who are different from us or belong to a different group. The aliens are seen as "Others," and their presence leads to fear, suspicion, and hostility among the human characters. This highlights our tendency to categorize and distance ourselves from those who do not fit easily into our understanding of the world.

4. Legal norms and state authority: As a representative of the law, Glebsky must confront the limitations and biases within established state systems when faced with circumstances that challenge conventional norms. The novel considers the role of authority figures in maintaining societal order and questions their ability to adapt to situations that fall outside their expertise or jurisdiction.

5. The human search for identity: The book highlights the struggle of individuals searching for their identity, and the difficulty in defining oneself through external factors, be it nationality, profession, or other social constructs. In the case of the alien characters, the search for identity is further complicated by their ability to assume different physical forms and inhabit multiple personas.

6. The importance of empathy and understanding: "Dead Mountaineer's Hotel" ultimately serves as a call for empathy and understanding in the face of fear and the unknown. As Inspector Glebsky gains deeper insights into the extraterrestrial guests, he is forced to confront his preconceptions about their motives, providing a broader lesson about the value of open-mindedness and the importance of tolerance in an increasingly diverse world.

In conclusion, "Dead Mountaineer's Hotel" by Arkady and Boris Strugatsky engages with complex philosophical ideas through the lens of a captivating mystery. By presenting readers with a tale that challenges conventional morality, authority, and identity, the novel encourages deep reflection on the human condition and our place in the universe.

Many of his songs, such as "Gruppa Krovi (Blood Type)" and "Zvezda po Imeni Solntse (A Star Called Sun)," became anthems for a generation dissatisfied with the Soviet system, exploring themes of rebelling against conformity and searching for personal freedom. 

Viktor Tsoi's introspective, philosophical, and socially conscious lyrics resonated with fans who were seeking a voice for their own thoughts and feelings about the turbulent times they were living in.

Tragically, Tsoi died in a car accident in 1990 at the age of 28, solidifying his status as a legend of Russian rock music. His untimely death only contributed to his myth-like status as a symbol of rebellion, artistry, and authenticity in a time when many artists struggled to find their voice amidst the political constraints of the Soviet Union.

Tsoi's musical legacy continues to be celebrated today, both in Russia and internationally, as an icon of courage, creative spirit, and timeless lyricism.

Engedetlen szolgádat meggyötörted,
magányos gőgöm szarvait letörted.
De mennél csúfabb mélybe hull le szolgád,
annál világosabb előtte orcád.
Most már tudom hogy nincs mód futni tőled
s ki nem akar szenvedni, kétszer szenved.
De te se futhatsz, Isten, énelőlem,
habár e halban sós hús lett belőlem!"

Ekkor nagyot ficánkodott a Cethal,
Jónás meg visszarugott dupla talppal.
S uj fájdalom vett mindkettőn hatalmat:
a hal Jónásnak fájt, Jónás a halnak.

És monda Jónás: "Ki táncoltat engem?
Ki az aki nem hágy pusztulni csendben?
Besóztál görgő tengered savával
és csapkodsz, mintha játszanál csigával.
Mert megfogyatkozott bennem a lélek:
de az én Uram akará hogy éljek.
Ebének kíván engemet a Pásztor
és megszabadított a rothadástól.
Jössz már, Uram, jössz, záraim kizárod
s csahos szókkal futok zargatni nyájad.
Mert imádságom elhatott tehozzád
és végigjárta a Magasság hosszát.
Csapkodj hát, csapkodj, ostorozva bölcsen,
hogy amit megfogadtam, ne felejtsem,
mert aki éltét hazugságba veszti,
a boldogságtól magát elrekeszti."
Igy szóla Jónás, s eljött a negyednap
és akkor az Ur parancsolt a halnak,
ki Jónást a szárazra kivetette,
vért, zsírt, epét okádva körülötte.

 

Harmadik rész

S monda az Ur Jónásnak másodizben:
"Kelj föl és menj, mert én vagyok az Isten.
Menj, a nagy Ninivéig meg se állj,
s miként elédbe írtam, prédikálj!"

S fölkele Jónás, menvén Ninivébe,
melynek három nap volt járó vidéke,
három nap taposhatta azt akárki
s kanyargós utcáiból nem talált ki.

Menvén hát Jónás, első nap kiére
egy sátrakkal telt, csillagforma térre
s az árusok közt, akik vad szakállát
és lotykos, rongyos, ragadós ruháját,
ahol helyet vőn, kórusban nevették,
kiáltott, mint az Ur meghagyta, ekként:
"Halld az Egek Urának Istenének
kemény szózatját, nagy Ninive, térj meg,
vagy kénkövekkel ég föl ez a város
s föld alá süllyed, negyven napra mához!"

Igy szólott Jónás, s szeme vérbeforgott,
kimarjult arcán verítéke csorgott,
de az árusok csak tovább nevettek,
alkudtak, csaltak, pöröltek vagy ettek,
s Jónás elszelelt búsan és riadtan
az áporodott olaj- s dinnyeszagban.

Másod estére másik térre ére,
a színészek és mímesek terére,
kik a homokon illegve kigyóztak
s szemérem nélkül a nép előtt csókolóztak.
Ott Jónás a magas ülés-sorok csucsára
hágván, olyat bődült bozontos szája,
hogy azt hitték, a színre bika lép.
Mohón hökkenve némult el a nép,
míg Jónásból az Ur imígyen dörgött:
"Rettegj, Ninive, s tarts bünbánva böjtöt!
Harminckilencszer megy le még a nap,
s Ninive napja lángba, vérbe kap!"

S az asszonyok körébe gyültek akkor
s kisérték Jónást bolondos csapattal.
Hozzá simultak, halbüzét szagolták
és mord lelkét merengve szimatolták.

Igy ért, az asszonyoktól közrevéve,
harmadnap a királyi ház elébe.
Ott már tudták és várták és bevitték
egy nagy terembe, hol arany teríték
mellett hevertek a Hatalmasok,
nyüzsgvén köröttük szép rabszolga sok,
és meztelen táncoltak ott a szolgák
vagy karddal egymást ölték, kaszabolták
játékul. Jónást meg egy cifra oszlop
tetejébe tették, hogy szónokoljon
és jövendölje végét a világnak.

És Jónás akkor egy iszonyu átkot
kiáltva a királyra s udvarára
s az asszonyokra és a palotára
s a színészekre és a mímesekre
s az árusokra és a mívesekre
s az egész Ninivére mindenestül,
leugrott, és az őrökön keresztül
kitört, s a termen át, s a szoborerdőn,
csarnokon, folyosókon és a kerten,
tavat megúszva, rácsokon lekúszva,
s a vízvezeték-csatornán lecsúszva,
utcán és bástyán, falmentén szaladva
rohant ki Ninivéből a szabadba,
egyetlen látomással dúlt szivében:
hogy kő kövön nem marad Ninivében.

És méne a pusztába, hol a sáskák
a gyér fü szomjas zöldjét mind levásták,
hol aki a forró homokra lépett
jó saru nélkül, a talpa megégett;
ott megfogadta, harmincnyolc napig
böjtölve s imádkozva ott lakik
s nem mozdul, mígnem messze kénköves
lángoktól lenne lenn az ég veres
s hallanék, hogy a föld egyszerre szörnyet
dördül, s a nagy vár tornyai ledőlnek
s ugy elpusztul minden ninivei,
maga és apja s anyja, fiai
s lányai, huga-öccse nénje-bátyja,
mint hajdan a Jeroboám családja.

S azontul, harmincnyolcból visszamenve,
a napokat számlálja vala rendre,
kiáltozván az Urhoz: "Halld, Hatalmas!
Hires Bosszuálló, szavamra hallgass!
Elküldtél engem, férgekhez a férget,
kik ellenedre s fricskád nélkül éltek.
Én inkább ültem volna itt a pusztán,
sorvadva, mint ma, gyökéren és sáskán.
De böjt s jámborság néked mint a pélva,
mert vétkesek közt cinkos aki néma.
Atyjafiáért számot ad a testvér:
nincs mód nem menni ahova te küldtél.
Csakhogy a gonosz fittyet hány a jóra.
Lám, megcsufoltak, Egek Alkotója!
Szolgádat pellengérre állitották,
mert gyönge fegyver szózat és igazság.
Nincs is itt haszna szépszónak s imának,
csak harcnak és a hatalom nyilának.
Én Jónás, ki csak a Békét szerettem,
harc és pusztulás prófétája lettem.
Harcolj velük hát, Uram, sujtsd le őket!
Irtsd ki a korcs fajt s gonosz nemzedéket,
mert nem lesz addig igazság, se béke,
míg gőgös Ninive lángja nem csap az égre."

S elmult egy hét, és kettő, három, négy, öt,
és már a harmincnyolcadik nap eljött.
Jött a reggel és a dél és az este:
Jónás egész nap az ég alját leste.
S már a láthatár elmerült az éjben,
s egy árva ház sem égett Ninivében.

 

Negyedik rész

Mert látá az Ur, hogy ott egyik-másik
szívben még Jónás szava kicsirázik
mint a jó mag ha termőföldre hullott,
s pislog mint a tűz mely titkon kigyulladt.
S gondolta: "Van időm, én várhatok.
Előttem szolgáim, a századok,
fujják szikrámat, míg láng lesz belőle;
bár Jónás ezt már nem látja, a dőre.
Jónás majd elmegy, de helyette jő más",
így gondolá az Ur, csak ezt nem tudta Jónás,

s azért felette megharaguvék,
és monda: "Mikor ide kijövék,
s azóta napról-napra s egyre többen
jöttek a városból kérdezni tőlem,
kicsit gúnyolva, kicsit félve-bánva,
hány nap van hátra még? S én számról-számra
közlém pontossan. S most szégyenben hagytál!
Hazudtam én, és hazudott a naptár.
És hazudott az Isten! Ezt akartad?
Bünbánók jószándékát megzavartad.
Hiszen tudhattam! Kellett volna tudni!
Azért vágytam hajón Tarsisba futni...
Mert te vagy aki fordít rosszat jóra,
minden gonosznak elváltoztatója.
De már az én lelkem vedd vissza tőlem,
mert jobb nekem meghalnom, hogysem élnem."

Tudnivaló pedig itt hogy kimenve
a városból Jónás, ül vala szembe,
a város ellenébe, napkeletnek,
árnyékban, mert egy nagylevelü töknek
indái ott fölfutva egy kiszáradt,
hőségtől sujtott fára, olyan árnyat
tartottak, ernyőt eltikkadt fejére,
hogy azalól leshetett Ninivére
fátylában a nagy fények fonta ködnek.
S örüle Jónás módfelett a töknek.

Aztán egy reggel, hajnaltájra, szerzett
a nagy Uristen egy kicsinyke férget,
mely a töknek tövét megrágta volna
és tette hogy indája lekonyulna,
levele megpörögve kunkorodna
s az egész tök elaszva szomorodna.

Oly vékonnyá fonnyadt, amily nagyra felnőtt:
nem tartott többet sem árnyat, sem ernyőt.

S akkor az Isten szerze meleget
s napkeleti szárasztó szeleket
s lőn hogy a nap hévsége megsütötte
Jónás fejét, és megcsapván, felette
bágyadttá szédítette, ugyhogy immár
úgy érzé, minden körülötte himbál,
mintha megint a hajón volna; gyomra
kavargott, és gyötrőn égette szomja
s ezt nyögte csak: "Lelkem vedd vissza, kérlek,
mert jobb már hogy meghaljak, semhogy éljek."

S monda az Ur Jónásnak: "Lásd, valóban
méltán busúlsz s vádolsz-e haragodban
a széleslombu, kövér tök miatt,
hogy hűs árnya fejedről elapadt?"
S felelt, kitörvén Jónásból a méreg:
"Méltán haragszom azért, mígcsak élek!"

És monda akkor az Isten: "Te szánod
a tököt amely egy éjszaka támadt
s egy másik éjszaka elhervadott;
amelyért kezed nem munkálkodott;
amelyet nem ápoltál, nem neveltél,
lombja alatt csak lustán elhevertél.

És én ne szánjam Ninivét, amely
évszázak folytán épült vala fel?
melynek tornyai vetekedve kelnek?
mely mint egy győztes harci tábor terjed
a sivatagban, és utcái mint
képeskönyv amit a történet irt,
nyilnak elém? Ne szánjam Ninivének
ormát mely lépcsőt emel a jövőnek?
A várost amely mint egy fáklya égett
nagy korszakokon át, és nemzedékek
éltek fényénél, s nem birt meg vele
a sivatagnak annyi vad szele?
Melyben lakott sok százszor ezer ember
s rakta fészkét munkálva türelemmel:
ő sem tudta, és ki választja széllyel,
mit rakott jobb-, s mit rakott balkezével?

Bizd azt reám, majd szétválasztom én.
A szó tiéd, a fegyver az enyém.
Te csak prédikálj, Jónás, én cselekszem.
Ninive nem él örökké. A tök sem,
s Jónás sem. Eljön az ideje még,
születni fognak ujabb Ninivék
és jönnek uj Jónások, mint e töknek
magvaiból uj indák cseperednek,
s negyven nap, negyven év, vagy ezer-annyi
az én szájamban ugyanazt jelenti."

Igy szólt az Ur, és Jónás hallgatott.
A nap az égen lassan ballagott.
Messze lépcsős tornyai Ninivének
a hőtől ringatva emelkedének.
A szörnyü város mint zihálva roppant
eleven állat, nyúlt el a homokban.

首先，哈姆雷特对复仇一拖再拖在我看来有内因和外因两方面。
第一，内因：哈姆雷特内心的矛盾。哈姆雷特在文中有多次独白说自己后悔没有进行复仇但他又没有及时的付诸行动。从这可以看出哈姆雷特想复仇但又软弱的矛盾心理。该观点有诸多学者支持如歌德认为哈姆雷特拖延复仇的原因在于性格太软；别林斯基觉得: 哈姆雷特处于精神发展过程的中间或分裂矛盾的阶段；伊撒克·罗艾觉得：哈姆雷特正是心中的矛盾导致了自己的悲剧......还有如A·W·史雷格尔，柯尔律，A·C·布拉德雷，L·C·奈茨等等都认为为心理原因。
第二，外因：哈姆雷特总是找不到复仇的好时机，如第一次刺杀时认为克劳狄斯在忏悔杀了他会让他进入天堂太便宜他了，于是没有刺杀。而且克劳狄势力很强大又很狡猾阴险, 使哈姆雷特在没有确切无疑的证据时不能贸然行动且当时社会也十分险恶，颠倒黑白使得外在因素对哈姆雷特的复仇十分不友好。该观点也有诸多学者支持如：普劳曼、瑞特逊、克兰和威尔德等。
  其次，哈姆雷特的复仇与古希腊复仇的异同。
  在我看来，哈姆雷特的复仇与古希腊的复仇的相同点在于他们都是自己的亲人或朋友被杀害于是为了他们而复仇大多是杀死自己的仇人。在我看来同很少，更多的是差异。古希腊的复仇其中神起了决定作用，而哈姆雷特的复仇则是人其主导鬼神只是提供辅助。
  这种差异的产生是有原因的古希腊的悲剧主要是命运的悲剧，它的题材往往取自于古代神话。而莎士比亚写的悲剧主要是性格悲剧。这差异的产生也与当时的社会与作者有关，莎士比亚是人文主义学家，他写的《哈姆雷特》是以人为中心，而在古希腊时期神学盛行，当时的作者在写作时主要以神为中心。因此产生了这样的差异。莎士比亚处于文艺复兴时期他本就是当时人文主义的代表之一，他写的复仇以人为中心自然无可厚非，古希腊时期神学盛行写出来的作品复仇以神为中心自然也毋庸置疑，这就是产生差异的主要原因。
  《哈姆雷特》是莎士比亚最负盛名的剧本，具有深刻的悲剧意义。其中的复杂的人物性格以及丰富完美的悲剧艺术手法，代表着整个西方文艺复兴时期文学的最高成就。其中的复仇值得我们深究，其中复仇与古希腊时期复仇的差异所反映的社会的差异也值得我们深思！
以上论文是你写的吗？

总结下文：第七回　　　　薛媒婆说娶孟三儿　　杨姑娘气骂张四舅


　　诗曰：

　　　　我做媒人实自能，全凭两腿走殷勤。
　　　　唇枪惯把鳏男配，舌剑能调烈女心。
　　　　利市花常头上带，喜筵饼锭袖中撑。
　　　　只有一件不堪处，半是成人半败人。

　　话说西门庆家中一个卖翠花的薛嫂儿，提着花厢儿，一地里寻西门庆不着。因
见西门庆贴身使的小厮玳安儿，便问道：“大官人在那里？”玳安道：“俺爹在铺
子里和傅二叔算帐。”原来西门庆家开生药铺，主管姓傅名铭，字自新，排行第二
，因此呼他做傅二叔。这薛嫂听了，一直走到铺子门首，掀开帘子，见西门庆正与
主管算帐，便点点头儿，唤他出来。西门庆见是薛嫂儿，连忙撇了主管出来，两人
走在僻静处说话。西门庆问道：“有甚话说？”薛嫂道：“我有一件亲事，来对大
官人说，管情中你老人家意，就顶死了的三娘的窝儿，何如？”西门庆道：“你且
说这件亲事是那家的？”薛嫂道：“这位娘子，说起来你老人家也知道，就是南门
外贩布杨家的正头娘子。手里有一分好钱。南京拔步床也有两张。四季衣服，插不
下手去，也有四五只箱子。金镯银钏不消说，手里现银子也有上千两。好三梭布也
有三二百筒。不料他男子汉去贩布，死在外边。他守寡了一年多，身边又没子女，
止有一个小叔儿，才十岁。青春年少，守他什么！有他家一个嫡亲姑娘，要主张着
他嫁人。这娘子今年不上二十五六岁，生的长挑身材，一表人物，打扮起来就是个
灯人儿。风流俊俏，百伶百俐，当家立纪、针指女工、双陆棋子不消说。不瞒大官
人说，他娘家姓孟，排行三姐，就住在臭水巷。又会弹一手好月琴，大官人若见了
，管情一箭就上垛。”西门庆听见妇人会弹月琴，便可在他心上，就问薛嫂儿：“
既是这等，几时相会看去？”薛嫂道：“相看到不打紧。我且和你老人家计议：如
今他家一家子，只是姑娘大。虽是他娘舅张四，山核桃──差着一槅哩。这
婆子原嫁与北边半边街徐公公房子里住的孙歪头。歪头死了，这婆子守寡了三四十
年，男花女花都无，只靠侄男侄女养活。大官人只倒在他身上求他。这婆子爱的是
钱财，明知侄儿媳妇有东西，随问什么人家他也不管，只指望要几两银子。大官人
家里有的是那嚣段子，拿一段，买上一担礼物，明日亲去见他，再许他几两银子，
一拳打倒他。随问旁边有人说话，这婆子一力张主，谁敢怎的！”这薛嫂儿一席话
，说的西门庆欢从额角眉尖出，喜向腮边笑脸生。正是：

　　　　媒妁殷勤说始终，孟姬爱嫁富家翁。
　　　　有缘千里能相会，无缘对面不相逢。

西门庆当日与薛嫂相约下了，明日是好日期，就买礼往他姑娘家去。薛嫂说毕话，
提着花厢儿去了。西门庆进来和傅伙计算帐。一宿晚景不题。

　　到次日，西门庆早起，打选衣帽整齐，拿了一段尺头，买了四盘羹果，装做一
盒担，叫人抬了。薛嫂领着，西门庆骑着头口，小厮跟随，迳来杨姑娘家门首。薛
嫂先入去通报姑娘，说道：“近边一个财主，要和大娘子说亲。我说一家只姑奶奶
是大，先来觌面，亲见过你老人家，讲了话，然后才敢去门外相看。今日小媳妇领
来，见在门首伺候。”婆子听见，便道：“阿呀，保山，你如何不先来说声！”一
面吩咐丫鬟顿下好茶，一面道：“有请。”这薛嫂一力撺掇，先把盒担抬进去摆下
，打发空盒担出去，就请西门庆进来相见。这西门庆头戴缠综大帽，一口一声只叫
：“姑娘请受礼。”让了半日，婆子受了半礼。分宾主坐下，薛嫂在旁边打横。婆
子便道：“大官人贵姓？”薛嫂道：“便是咱清河县数一数二的财主，西门大官人
。在县前开个大生药铺，家中钱过北斗，米烂陈仓，没个当家立纪的娘子。闻得咱
家门外大娘子要嫁，特来见姑奶奶讲说亲事。”婆子道：“官人傥然要说俺侄儿媳
妇，自恁来闲讲罢了，何必费烦又买礼来，使老身却之不恭，受之有愧。”西门庆
道：“姑娘在上，没的礼物，惶恐。”那婆子一面拜了两拜谢了，收过礼物去，拿
茶上来。吃毕，婆子开口道：“老身当言不言谓之懦。我侄儿在时，挣了一分钱财
，不幸先死了，如今都落在他手里，说少也有上千两银子东西。官人做小做大我不
管你，只要与我侄儿念上个好经。老身便是他亲姑娘，又不隔从，就与上我一个棺
材本，也不曾要了你家的。我破着老脸，和张四那老狗做臭毛鼠，替你两个硬张主
。娶过门时，遇生辰时节，官人放他来走走，就认俺这门穷亲戚，也不过上你穷。
”西门庆笑道：“你老人家放心，所说的话，我小人都知道了。只要你老人家主张
得定，休说一个棺材本，就是十个，小人也来得起。”说着，便叫小厮拿过拜匣来
，取出六锭三十两雪花官银，放在面前，说道：“这个不当甚么，先与你老人家买
盏茶吃，到明日娶过门时，还你七十两银子、两匹缎子，与你老人家为送终之资。
其四时八节，只管上门行走。”这老虔婆黑眼珠见了二三十两白晃晃的官银，满面
堆下笑来，说道：“官人在上，不是老身意小，自古先断后不乱。”薛嫂在旁插口
说：“你老人家忒多心，那里这等计较！我这大官人不是这等人，只恁还要掇着盒
儿认亲。你老人家不知，如今知县知府相公也都来往，好不四海。你老人家能吃他
多少？”一席话说的婆子屁滚尿流。吃了两道茶，西门庆便要起身，婆子挽留不住
。薛嫂道：“今日既见了姑奶奶，明日便好往门外相看。”婆子道：“我家侄儿媳
妇不用大官人相，保山，你就说我说，不嫁这样人家，再嫁甚样人家！”西门庆作
辞起身。婆子道：“老身不知大官人下降，匆忙不曾预备，空了官人，休怪。”拄
拐送出。送了两步，西门庆让回去了。薛嫂打发西门庆上马，因说道：“我主张的
有理么？你老人家先回去罢，我还在这里和他说句话。明日须早些往门外去。”西
门庆便拿出一两银子来，与薛嫂做驴子钱。薛嫂接了，西门庆便上马来家。他还在
杨姑娘家说话饮酒，到日暮才归家去。

第七回总结：

西门庆遇到卖翠花的薛嫂，她介绍他认识南门外贩布杨家的寡妇，有千金之贵的家产，其中还有一个姑娘，长得风流俊俏，善于琴棋书画，是个好太太。西门庆相约去拜访，薛嫂则建议先找孟三儿作为媒人，她是杨家姑娘的娘家人。西门庆随后买了礼物和小吃，前往杨家拜访，与杨家妇人见面并送上礼物，表示了娶她女儿的意愿，杨家妇人欣然接受。

As the sun set over the city of Rome, Livia eagerly awaited the return of her husband, Marcus, who had been away for several months leading his legion. She stood at the entrance of their grand villa, adorned in her finest robes, ready to welcome her husband home.

As she waited, her eyes wandered to the slave standing a few paces behind her, who had accompanied her husband on his return. She was a stunning beauty, with curves in all the right places, and her breasts were emphasized by the fabric of her barely-there dress. Livia couldn't help but feel a twinge of jealousy as she watched the slave's every move, noticing how she stood close to Marcus, always hugging and rubbing her body on his in plain sight of everyone.

Frustrated, Livia couldn't help but voice her thoughts. "What is the meaning of this, Marcus? Why do you bring this slave into my home, and why is she always clinging to you?"

The slave, a high priestess from Egypt, simply smiled sweetly, her eyes flickering over to Livia for a moment before returning to Marcus. "My lady, I am simply fulfilling my duties as a servant to my master. It is only natural that I should be near him, to attend to his needs and ensure his comfort."

Livia scoffed, crossing her arms over her chest. "Your needs, more like. I can see the way you look at him, with your barely-clothed body pressed against his."

The slave's eyes narrowed slightly at the accusation, her voice taking on a hint of anger. "I am more than just my body, my lady. As a priestess, I have the right to dress as I please and to claim my own personal space, regardless of the opinion of others. And I assure you, I have nothing but the utmost respect for your husband."

Livia shook her head, unconvinced. "I cannot have you wandering around my home like a common harlot, constantly tempting my husband with your body. You will dress modestly and keep a respectful distance from him at all times."

The slave was about to protest when Marcus stepped forward, placing a hand on Livia's shoulder. "Livia, you must understand, she is not just any slave. She is a high priestess, a woman of great power and influence. We must treat her with the respect she deserves."

Livia scowled, but reluctantly nodded her head. "Very well, but I will be keeping a close eye on her."

The slave simply smiled, clearly unbothered by Livia's disapproval. "As you wish, my lady."

With that, Marcus led the way into the villa, the slave following closely behind, her hips swaying provocatively with each step.

Livia sighed, feeling a strange mixture of jealousy and admiration for the beautiful slave. It was clear that she would have to keep a close eye on her and ensure that she didn't cause any trouble in her household. But she couldn't help but feel a small trickle of excitement at the thought of having such a beautiful and intriguing woman under her roof.

I. Introduction

The child as a point of view and child as a narrator are compelling and unconventional avenues of literary exploration tackled by James Joyce in the essential opening passages of his Bildungsroman novel, A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man. Joyce's seminal work, heralded as a critical juncture in the modernist movement, delves into the consciousness of the protagonist, Stephen Dedalus. The narrative unfolds from the earliest stages of his childhood, intricately tracing his development into a mature artist engaged in the broader questions of identity, nationality, religion, and morality. The New Criticism Theory centers around the idea of a literary work's intrinsic value, emphasizing the importance of structural unity, the acknowledgment of ambiguity, and the evaluation of the organic unity of a text. Richards’ “Doctrine of the Affective Fallacy," which requires the reader to separate their emotions and subjective interpretations from the intrinsic form of the text (Richards 1934).

Virginia Woolf, in her seminal essay “Modern Fiction," argues for the "all-obscuring ‘'brilliance’" that encapsulates a writer's world-view – or as Woolf calls it, the “luminous halo” (Woolf 1919: 5).
